												Please bear in mind that this review will be about the singleplayer, and the singleplayer only. I haven't played the multi, and does not plan to do so. Why? I'm an SP man, that's why. So, let's begin.If you've played the original MoH series, it could get really different. Instead of a more realistic game, you get Band of Brothers: The Shooter. And I love every single minute of it. You get six rather short missions that you can complete in about 5 hours (or in my case, 7, because I'm a terrible aim), and each mission lets you refight one airborne operation of the war. The first two takes place in Italy, and it quickly grabs your attention if you let it do so. Fast paced action with loud guns, and more enemies that you can count. The more you kill, the better your weapons will be. For every kill, your weapon gets experience, and when it "levels up", you get an upgrade for it. Like grenade launcher for the M1 Garand, better scope for the Springfield, dual mag for the Stg44, and so forth. Maybe not entirely accurate, but certainly gives you a feel of progression.Try to stick with a weapon if you like it, tho. Some weapons appear only in early game (like the Kar98k and the Mp40), sor maybe it's wiser to use something that will be present a bit more frequent to let you get ammo for it. I recommend the pistol, because it doesn't require you to get additional ammo for it - you have infinite bullets. And that's cool, because on lvl 3, it's a really powerful weapon in short to middle range firefights. But the rest repends on your gamestyle. You can level up grenades too. Spam Gammon grenades for supernazis, and you can bear quite an amount of them to help you get baddies out fo the way.The cons? Well, they are present. It's not much a historical game, rather than a historical based shooter. The Kar98k was used throughoutly the war, as well as the Mp40 - and believe it or not, not every men had an Stg44, and there wasn't any (or rather - that much) super nazis who could shoot the 15kg (possibly more) MG42 from the hip. And it's a bit frustrating when you go back to a place after they shot you, and it's swarming with enemies. Oh, before I forget - spawning. If you die, you'll make another jump where you can choose where to deploy. Rather neat function, that contains some interesting elements as there are skill jumps on each level, like land on the balcony or the catwalk.Overall, a good game. Really short, so I'd recommend getting it on a sale or if you are really don't have much else to spend you hard earned money on. If you want a bit more realistic FPS that have the Airborne in it, try Brothers in Arms - especially Hell's Highway, but it's just my personal preference.

												"It looked like an easy victory, but after the last battle; we can see it's not as easy as we thought." With the WWII Spam of the early 2000's, you would think they would die out. With the release of Medal of Honor: Airborne WWII Is back and has a few different changes. Should it be a good pickup? Or just another game that's late of the WWII Spam?Story/Design: Airborne invites players to fly and dive into the skies of multiple famous battles as Boyd Travers. Not much about the guy, but hey, none really did with the other WWII games. With select battles from other MoH titles like Market Garden, and of course Normandy. (Since every WWII game needed a reference to the battle of Normandy.) There isn't too much story to it, just going to objective to objective and accomplish them. They range from taking out a group of targets to go and blow up some artillery guns to help your other airborne comrades. The game is decent looking, a medium rig could run it but it looks quite nice on a great rig. With it being released in 2007, even some of the other games had a few better sounds. The firearm shot sounds don't ruin the game, but with others at the time it could be a bit better. With the story, there isn't much to it. Objective here, and objective there but luckily you're doing objectives during more famous battles that are usually well done and you can choose how you go to each of the objectives instead of a linear path, which is a spectacular change from go here, cut scene and follow the linear AI path. Gameplay/Mechanics: No more running and gunning or running out and blasting each brain-dead AI in the face to reach the next objective. MoH Airborne takes things to a new level with some great changes added to the WWII FPS standards. As you dive out of the plane at each start point and choose where you would like to land, it is all up to you. Either landing in safe zones with your team or directly in enemy sights; the enemy AI is brutal and ruthless, able to hit you from rather large distances, and can seem a bit cheap at times; but it's much better than having brain-dead AI who just sit there until you shoot their face. Of course with the AI being so brutal and checkpoints usually not showing up until you finally clear an objective; this can lead to starting from the plane over and over and over again. It's fine the first few times, but after the 6th time of doing the same thing you'll want to just rage quit. The game is more slowly paced than a few other FPS's. Aiming down the sights will stop your character from walking around and instead be able to duck, lean, and raise your character instead of just walking around. This is a better choice so you can take it more slowly since the AI will be on your trail the whole time. Shooting hundreds of Nazi's and common soldiers will with the same gun will lead to a level up system to it, causing the game to slow-motion for a few seconds and to tell you what you unlocked for the following gun. Whether it be extended mag, reduced recoil, or better fire rate this can help you choose what gun firearm you love to use most and is a welcome addition to the standard FPS. The game can offer replay ability for the ones who want everything unlocked, such as landing in certain spots while parachuting. For the gameplay, the AI is brutal and the checkpoints can be rather annoyingly placed. The gunplay is fun and great to control with a great gun level up type system.Overall this is one of the best WWII games I have played, with smarter AI and a few different takes on a few things; although not being a completely perfect FPS experience, it's definitely a step in the right direction for a WWII game. 8/10 Excellent WWII FPS

												After a long line of disappointing games in the Medal of Honor franchise that just never could recapture the magic successes of Allied Assault, we finally get Medal of Honor: Airborne that combines high presentation values and good, fast-paced fun. While there's definitely some good entertainment value here, the campaign is short, and the multiplayer isn't incredibly deep. Still, it's a good game overall and the best game in the franchise in some time.Medal of Honor: Airborne takes a different approach to World War II shooters. Instead of starting players out in each linear level on a path where there's no variation, EA LA decided to let us choose where to start each mission by throwing us out of a plane. Once floating in the air, it's a matter of steering the parachute to the best location to start the fight. Where the best location is depends on how you want to play the game, a mechanic that certainly is useful if you want a challenge or find that it's more fun to start out in a certain place on a map. It also provides an opportunity to drop into a new location if the previous one was a little too difficult or even complete one of the five different skill drops (drops in very specific areas).

												A timeless WWII classic that is a must-play for any WWII gamer who wants a good 'ol fashioned shooter with a unique first person cover system and great gameplay. One note before you buy this game is you may get a "video card not supported issue". I believe this was fixed because on my new PC I got a popup to set up game settings, similar to Rust and The Forest, and I've had no issues, but I can't 100% confirm you won't get this issue. If you do get it there is a few simple fixes relating to your .exe and setting up custom launch options and it's just a simple google search. Pros-Gunplay is smooth.-Characters are realistic and have some decent dialogue when you're fighting, even if a little repetitive outside cutscenes.-Ability to choose different routes when assaulting your various objectives, with different routes through houses, tunnels, and even going up and through rooftops. You also have the option to land anywhere in your mission, which can give you either the extra edge, or you land in a terrible spot either with no movement or completely surrounded by Germans.-Entertaining story taking you through various parts of the European Theatre, with some small fictionalized enemies and events to fight through and against.-Ability to upgrade weapons through kills. Want a thompson with a drum mag? 3rd unlock. Want a trench shotgun with a bayonet? I can't remember which upgrade but you'll get it. Want that special dual magazine loading MP40 giving you a total mag count of 64 rounds? Yep, 3rd unlock and it's awesome.-A small multiplayer following averaging from around 4-12 players on 1 or 2 servers. Really friendly community, and expect to see the same guys on different servers. They're all really nice and fun to play with, and they're always welcome new players.-Graphics hold up even in 2015, especially on High settings. The game still looks beautiful.Cons-Possiblity of motion sickness or vertigo due to the verticality of the maps and cover system. This game can make you feel ill or give you headaches after a while if you're not careful.-Lack of movement with cover system. Not neccesarilly a true "con" since the cover system is WASD based, but it can sometimes be a little awkward.-AI can sometimes be too easy, even on Expert, enemies generally go towards MG positions despite taking fire, and don't run from cover often, allowing you to rush them and hipfire. Then again, this game is from 2007, so it's to be expected, it just makes the game a little boring at times.Overall I give the game a 9/10. For $10 you'll get a pretty fun ride, pretty good multiplayer, just be careful that you don't get sick or hurt your eyes, and that you may plow through the AI at times.

												The Brothers in Arms series is my favorite in the WW2 FPS genre, but this is definitely my second favorite. It's essentially the same formula you see in most WW2 shooters, but instead of having linear levels, each mission is a reasonably large map with multiple objectives that you can take on in any order. The game drops you into the map by airplane, and you can parachute to wherever you want to start (there are designated green smoke "safe zones" where the enemies don't spawn, but you're generally free to experiment with landing wherever you think would give you the best advantage). You can find a decent amount of standard WW2 guns throughout the levels, and each of them has 3 levels of upgrade attachments that you unlock after getting a certain amount of kills with each one. With that being said, there's a reason it's only my second favorite. For one thing, the game is really short - it only has 6 missions, which each last somewhere close to an hour each. They're largely unconnected, and for the most part the other soldiers are all just a bunch of faces, with no real narrative or characters to give more purpose to the nazi killing like you might be used to in other shooters in the genre. The game's AI is also pretty severely lacking, and tend to navigate the levels in a way that hints that they weren't really ready to make a game where you aren't on a set path. It's not usually noticeable for the enemies that are spawned into the game when you first begin a mission, but for freshly spawned enemies and allies it can be pretty bad. Overall I'd still recommend it, if only because it's so old now that it's only $10, which in my opinion is worth it for a game as fun as this even as short as it is. But if $10 for 6 hours isn't enough for you, it might be better to wait for a sale. Either way, I'd recommend it if you like WW2 games.

												Bought this game by accident while drunk after getting home from a party.  Played it for an hour and found it fun enough to keep, but not fun enough to play a lot.  Recently I've had some sort of a Medal of Honor itch. I really wanted to relive some of those great memories I had with the earlier games.  I tried the first game on an emulator, found it charming but dated. Frontline looks ghastly these days.  Allied Assault, which was by far my favorite back in the day, has not aged that well either.  It was groundbreaking at the time, but it has not aged the way other classics such as Half Life have.  Then I came to this game.  The main difference between this game and the others is it seems to depart from the setpieces and story focus of the other games and is almost entirely gameplay focused. There are no pre-rendered cutscenes, everything happens in game.  Each mission you choose your weapons, jump out of a plane, control your parachute and decide where to land, and start completeing objectives. You can coplete them in whatever order you want.  You can also choose your combat style, etiher you can take point and advance with an SMG, or lay back, hit the rooftops and provide covering sniper fire for your squad as they advance.   The health system is also a nice combination of regeneration and old school depletion which was done even better in the new wolfenstein games.  The graphics aren't great but they aren't terrible either. The weapons feel nice, especially the Kar98 and the Thompson, and you recieve upgrades the more you use them.  The more you play this game it can kind of feel like you are playing a multiplayer Call of Duty with bots and can get old for sure, but as far as the Medal of Hono games go, it's currently hte most fun to play.

												This game can be infuriating. But it can also be a lot of fun.It took me 12 hours to beat the game and then go back and get all the weapon upgrades for every weapon and the grenades. AI IssuesThe enemy AI is extremely dumb and very spastic, they will hunker down against an object and keep repositioning themselves so they become impossible to shoot sometimes and they can straight up teleport because of the AI's cover system. They move around so much even when un-alerted, they give us sufferers of ADHD a bad name. They can shoot you through walls and the tiniest cracks in them and other objects. They never miss a grenade throw and some single enemies can chuck EIGHT grenades at you in a split second. They've thrown grenades through tiny cracks in the walls that are impossible for the grenades to fit through and yet they still manage to go through. Your teammates are just useless cannon fodder but amusingly they'll sometimes band together and run at the enemies and all of them melee a single enemy at once running this devilishy satisfying fist train on them and insta kill the enemy sending their body FLYING. The enemies do this too, even to you, they'll come around a corner while you're reloading and ONLY ever do it while you're reloading and run the train on you and instantly kill you. Your teammates WILL ALWAYS get in your way and probably get you killed, they can softly push you around and block your ironsight peeking and they'll do it all the time. They'll run through you and in front of you and sometimes they follow where you're aiming and do nothing but follow your crosshair to be shot, like no joke, seriously. The enemy AI are also aim-botting ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. No matter what weapon they're using, they'll shoot you from a far distance and get a headshot and take 50% of your health. And other times, they're super dumb and miss every shot, but most of the  time they land every shot even if their gun is aiming at the ground and they're running the other way. Their bullets can apparently eject out of their barrel at a sharp 90 degree angle and they can blindfire around any object and ALWAYS hit you. It's never missed me once, even when I'm behind cover. And a common problem, you'll enter a new area before there's any cover and you'll be shot by every enemy there at the same time instantly killing you. Your teammates will almost always cause the RPG enemies to hit you, they'll run across the battlefield and the RPG enemy fires at them and it completely misses them and hits you even if you're behind cover even when the RPG enemy has no clue where you are, thanks to your useless cannon fodder buddies. I died more times because of this than any other means of death in this game. It happens with the tanks too. I've walked through a door my buddy ran through only to be hit in the face by a tank shell and insta-killed.Enemies also have infinite clips and randomly reload even if they don't need to and RPG guys? They can fire as many rockets as they want without reloading and then all of a sudden they decide to reload the rocket launcher only to fire it at you again before they've even dropped the rocket in the launcher, and they can be facing the other way and then just turn around and fire instantly exactly where you're standing, all enemies do this though so it's to be expected, even snipers can one shot kill you like this as well. And mind you, this entire time, I'm playing on NORMAL, not HARD. I tried hard and it's almost exactly the same, but their weapons do more damage, that's the only difference, you can be shot twice by an MP40 and die but it can take a whole clip from a Thompson to down a single enemy. And even in normal mode, most enemies can take more bullets to their face than you can but a grenade at 20ft away or rocket of the same distance is insta death to them but not you if you have full health.Your buddies will also almost always fail their grenade throws and it bounces back right on top of you which can damage you. Your grenades also kill your buddies, so if you throw one, your buddy will 99% of the time try to play fetch with you and be blown clear across the sky where he is truly part of the Airborne now.BugsThis game has no option to adjust FOV and I had to adjust it using the fixes provided on PCGWiki. It's a normal problem with UE3 games and you need to adjust the FOV every time you start a new level, with the fix you just hit Page Down to make the FOV accurate. Also, get rid of the sprint effects if you don't want to get motion sickness.You can get stuck in the map, especially on stair cases or closed quarters, normally you can just crouch, jump or sprint out of it but sometimes you need to kill yourself.Parachute landings are borked? My landings always range from terrible to perfect and the drop points are kind of dumb, they're really hard to even see because of the super restricted camera angle while parachuting and you need to apparently play a level five times just to get each secret drop location and they're not highlighted once you find them on foot either even though it tells you "Secret Drop Discovered!" and sometimes they don't even work or are really wonky, I've landed the exact same way on multiple secret drops and it's a 50% chance I'll succeed in the exact same method.Game uses some kind of mouse smoothing that causes your crosshair to move over objects instead of directly on them. And for the love of GOD, do yourself a favor and turn off the motion blur. There are also bugs with the DOF in this game too, it takes FOREVER for it to accurately adjust to where you're looking and sometimes if an object near you is close to your crosshair it won't adjust at all, your teammates can cause this to happen too if they're inside you.ConclusionBut despite all that? I really like this game. It pisses me off, but the gunplay, graphics, audio, controls and especially the ragdoll system all make up for it for me. It's an incredibly short game, only ten missions that you can beat in twenty minutes each. But for some reason, I really liked this game. I've played all the Medal of Honor games and even though this game feels like it's missing polish and feels rushed, I enjoyed it for some reason. It feels like a good productive time waster that doesn't require hundreds of hours to beat or collect everything. I feel the length was perfect.

												It's a good game with some unique gameplay while parachuting into open levels and choosing where to start the missions. There's also an interesting AI system used with the enemies called Affordance AI. Which causes them to move around and take cover in a fun and engaging way. Most of the guns feel great especialy the sniper rifles with some cool lensing effects on the scopes. There's not much of a story but there's a couple of shocking moments that make up for this especialy towards the end. I also liked the way the missions are introduced and I think the developers made some good design choices to encourage immersion. I played casualy through all the missions in about 9 hours and unlocked around a third of the extra content and weapon upgrades. The last two levels are particularly good and where the game really comes into it's own. There's some replay value here too with all the unlockable stuff. There's also a multiplayer mode which I didn't try. However I read online that a group called War Lions has kept this mode alive. The game runs in 1080p at a solid 60FPS for me, on a GTX 980 with Windows 10. I read that some people have needed to install legacy Physx drivers to get it to work, I didnt have this problem. The graphics still look pretty good and can be ehanched to look even better with SweetFx. The game is unfortunately fairly blurry though when moving around. However motion blur can be disabled by editing the .ini files which helps this a lot. The FOV can also be increased in the same way.So with a few tweaks the game runs pretty good for me, certainly enough to enjoy the experience. It can still be a bit blurry but it's definitely worth playing regardless. At the time it was released in late 2007, the developers seemed to be genuinely trying something different and for the most part it works. It reminds me of Wolfenstein (2009) I even got a bit of a supernatural vibe off one of the Nazi enemies during the later missions. I had a lot of fun with this one and I highly recommend it.

Posted: February 8, 2016
												Not your traditional MoH, but still a great game nonetheless. What sets Airborne apart from previous MoH games is that you are not a single agent sneaking behind enemy lines; instead, you are a paratrooper dropping into a large scale battle. The “one man army” feeling is nonetheless preserved, for better or worse. Fellow NPC paratroopers accompany you throughout each mission, though their combat effectiveness is questionable. They neither help nor hinder you very much in gameplay, though they at least provide cinematic backdrop for sense of a larger scale ground battle. Perhaps the biggest difference between Airborne and past MoH games is its nonlinearity. At the beginning of each level you (as the title might suggest) jump out of an airplane and land on the battlefield. During this jump you can steer your character towards anywhere you want to land (to an extent). Upon landing you are tasked with completing a number of objectives which are spread throughout the map. You may carry out these objectives in any order you please before a new area is unlocked through which you will complete the finale to the mission. This is a far cry to previous games of the series and in some ways it is therefore lacking. There are much less cinematic moments in Airborne that the series has been known for (like running across a family having dinner in Frontline), and entire missions take place in relatively the same battleground. In this vein, the game is somewhat disappointing. However, this it makes up in replayability. The singleplayer campaign clocks in around 5 hours long on normal (which is a bit short), however the freedom to start missions (almost) wherever you want and complete objectives in any order you want allows for exta hours of gameplay in comparison to MoH’s generally more scripted level design. In addition, there are various unlockables and collectibles such as weapon upgrades (unlocked by killing enemies) and “skill drops” (marked places on the map where you can land).If collectibles aren’t something you’re particularly into, the gameplay itself is a blast. Each weapon is punchy and satisfying to use. At the start of a each mission you can choose your own loadout, allowing for multiple playstyles. Want to land on a rooftop and pick off your enemies with a sniper rifle? You can do that. Want to run and gun through the streets with a thompson? You can do that too. To that end, the game allows you to choose your own pace. You can race through the mission if you please, completing objectives as quickly as possible, or you can simply take your time, picking off enemies one by one. In gameplay, Airborne truly does feel a lot like a MoH game, yet more open to different playstyles. One unique feature in Airborne is a Ravenshield-esque leaning system. Whilst aiming down the sights you can press the WASD keys to lean your character to and fro in different directions. Unfortunately, whilst doing this, you cannot move from where you are standing (unless you hold shift as I later found out). It is by no means a bad feature, but its implementation is strange and makes movement in the game awkward sometimes. The game would certainly benefit from the ability to toggle this feature but alas, there is none.Airborne offers a new experience for MoH veterans, perhaps not one they may have hoped for, but a fun one nonetheless. Hardcore fans may have trouble accepting Airborne as a true MoH game, and maybe it isn’t, but it is by no means worth passing up.

There´s always more than one way of flanking a certain situation, there´s always more than one objective you can choose to go to (or fall into) The game is specially fun if played in the hardest level of difficulty, where you really feel the need to "supress" and you get supressed most of the time (you even get routed away if you want to survive when you see those nazis outnumber your guys and charge against you, those are funny moments)This one is an ""old"" game now, by modern super-graphic standards, but it aged very very well, and  if you want a single player experience that "feels" a lot like a multiplayer with lots of moments of script, right now is selling at 2,5 dollars, it´s really a bargain and it´s worth it.

Posted: December 26, 2016
												Medal of Honor: Airborne is a wild, wild WW2 ride. Over the course of six missions (not much, yeah), you parachute behind enemy lines, complete various objectives in any order you want, then move on to some grand finale for the level. The weapons you use level up with kills, like scopes and taped magazines. There isn't much meat on the story, but the locations are diverse enough to make you want to finish the game at least once.Some of the better aspects are sadly uncommon in most modern shooters. You can start anywhere you want on the map thanks to the parachuting mechanic, then complete the level in almost any way you want. Even though the gun leveling can be grindy for underpowered weapons like the Kar98k, it's worth it for the enhancements and fun mods that come with it. Can anyone say full grenade restocks for rifles with grenade launchers, and a dagger for the MP40 that sends enemies flying on melee kills?Unfortunately, the game is short, and aside from the completionist stuff you won't find much of a reason to keep going after replaying the best levels. Also, the melee system is pretty weak without the BAR's bayonet or the MP40's dagger: enemies will charge you and bash you to death while your screen flashes white, all while your wimpy melee attacks fail to hold them off. The difficulty has serious slopes to deal with, especially when you deal with several sniper nests at once in the 5th mission. The last mission is almost a cakewalk compared to it, even with all of its unique challenges. The multiplayer is basically dead, so don't expect to find many people to play with. Also, the game has an issue with PhysX that requires manual fixing. There are guides on Steam that explain how to do it in a straightforward way.I would recommend getting this game on sale for half off or more. It's a fun experience overall, but it's too short to justify spending more than five dollars.

(That being said, the gameplay doesn't varymuch from *stuff gun in hand and run into battlefield to blow things up.* But this game makes that fun, and somehow feel varied.)- Even though it's a little old now, the graphics aren't antique; pretty good for a game nearing a decade old.- Sniping is my jam and this game does it well. You feel powerful when you can headshot a helmet from the other side of the map. You don't complete many/any objectives doing this but it's fun all the same and is encouraged due to vertically versatile maps.You'll have lots of chances to snipe.- Spotting a stick grenade as it lands at your feet and kicking it back into a cluster of enemies. - The final mission is lovely. A huge AA obstacle swarming with the enemies you love to dread (you'll know the ones) that to all intents and purposes seems undefeatable. But you worm your way deeper into its machinery and ... well you'll find out the rest. You feel great when you finish the game and will want more.- Gammon grenades. Pack a Comp-B charge into a grenade the size of a small melon and underarm it into an Anti-Aircraft turret. Just do it.Bad Points:- Short campaign! I could have played a campaign twice as long. (Would love an Airborne sequel.)- Upgrading your weapons (with one or two exceptions) gives you only one of two final modifications: granade launcher attachment, or scope attachment. I guess you either have to love blowing things up or sniping things. ***SNIPING THINGS***- Glitches. Prepare to see a fallen enemy turn his ragdoll body into a twisted knot of limbs once in a while. You get this in many games. You know the drill: don't look directly at the glitches.- My laptop runs the game perfectly except for a little lighting bug where some characters and objects in cutscenes occasionally look opaque black. The projector image in the briefing tent doesn't show up because of this either. I know the missions so don't need the briefing but I can imagine it might be annoying for a new player who runs into the same bug.- Parachuting is hard to control on the PC and you'll run into lots of invisible walls in the sky if you try and parachute too far. That first ten seconds of a mission isn't a detriment to the game though.- CAMPAIGN TOO SHORT.Overall I'd rate a 7/10.

Posted: March 15
												This isn't a BAD game. Medal of Honor: Airborne is fun for half of its campaign, and it has things that set it apart from both the other games in the Medal of Honor series, and other FPS games - especially the paradrop system, which is a neat way to try out a new approach to getting past its nasty difficulty. While it is fun, it has several glaring problems that make it difficult to recommend. First, the difficulty. Airborne seems to be a cover-based shooter (Not with the systems like in Gears of War or other such games, but there is an emphasis on not running-and-gunning). Enemies do a lot of damage and rip through your health easily if you're not absurdly careful. This is enjoyable at times, especially when you only realize after you land that you're surrounded and manage to fight your way out regardless. Later on, the difficulty ramps from unfair to unforgiving, with juggernaut-type enemies that are extremely difficult to take down and snipers that seem to be able to fire through their own cover, making it impossible to counterattack. The less said about the sniper-accurate rocket launchers employed against you, the better.Second, the AI. The enemy AI is fantastic, and they put up a challenging fight throughout the game. They react how you would expect a trained army to react, pinning you under suppressive fire and using grenades to flush you out of cover. Later on, this again becomes relentless, especially when you compare it to the ally AI, which is comparatively pitiful. Your allies are either gunned down in seconds, run directly into your line of fire, or take cover near you and inadvertently push you into enemy fire. The enemy AI is almost too good when your allies are held against them, because you can never count on their support. (I also encountered a glitch where having an ally even nearby would cause the crosshairs to 'x' out as though I was aiming at a friendly, when I was aiming at an enemy instead. This got old, fast.)Third, and most damning, was the gunplay. I can only describe it as excessively slippery. Without turning the sensitivity near the bottom, I was unable to hit just about anything even when given time to line up a shot, and when scoped weapons came into play, I might as well have been hip-firing with the pistol. I'm not even bad at first-person shooters, generally. I had to grind to get the upgraded SMG and pistol to even stand a chance in close combat, and when the juggernaut enemies came into play later, it was a crapshoot whether they could be beat or not. Not to mention, this cover-based shooter seems to have infinite enemy spawns - meaning that bizarrely, the most effective strategy was to try and sprint across the flanks of the enemy to get close enough to spray-and-pray. TLDR: Brutally difficult, shoddy ally AI, bad gunplay, INFINITE ENEMY SPAWNS. It's still aged better than older MoH games, but that's not stiff competition, and you're better off spending your money elsewhere.

												Disclaimer (Sorry for my english)I will start from the beggining. This game is AWESOME, but it`s AWESOME for me not that it has great graphics or a wonderful multiplayer, no it doesn`t, but this game and aspecialy Medal of Honor series lie deep in my heart, because these were my favourite games in my childhood (Allied Assault, Spearhead, Breakthrough, Pacific Assault, Airborne and so on) and thats why I can`t say anything bad about them, because I love them the way they are. But still, I will let you guys know my neutral opinion about this game. It is underrated, people just dont even know that this game exists, because call of duty, counter strike and other popular shooters rule the gaming market. The singleplayer is short, the AI sometimes (ussualy) makes stupid things, texture problems (minor), bugs and so on. But the story for me was very interesting and the way you enter a mission each time is truly something new: after jumping of a plane the game lets you decide wich objective you want to complete, where you want to land, what guns you want to use. Personaly I replayed the singleplayer ALOT of times, and every time it didn`t get boring for me. My personal rating would be 9/10 for the singleplayer.Multiplayer- very unbalanced, each time you die (allied side) you spawn in your parashute, yes it is fun to get on top of the building or take a view over the battlefield, but it is a pain in the butt when you get spawned killed by the enemy, because they see you, where you landed, also the maps are small for the parashuting, you don`t have so much landing spots to choose. Also there are currently 3 servers running, sometimes I see 50 people playing, sometimes I see empty servers, it`s a shame that it happend like this. My personal rating for the multiplayer would be 7/10In the end, my rating is 8/10 for this game. I would reccomend buying this game if you`re a fan of WW2 games, if you`re a fan of MOH series, or just you like to parashute from the skies and kill bunch of nazi soldiers :)

												A very interesting mechanic poorly executed.Being able to jump out of a plane to land anywhere on the field is a neat idea. You can land on a roof and shoot your way down, or land behind the enemy and flank them.And that’s about where the good ends.The weapons have a neat level-up mechanic. The more you use a certain weapon, you will earn attachments for it, and make it better. Unfortunately, at the beginning of the game when you don’t have any proficiencies, the weapons are incredibly difficult to use. I remember having a rifle, looking down the sights at an enemy’s chest, and emptying entire magazines without a single hit. The inaccuracy of the weapons in this game can make it very frustrating.The enemies scale, and get more difficult as you progress. That’s good. The highest level enemies, though, are laughable and unrealistic. Also, after five legitimate missions, the sixth and final mission feels like a giant spoof of the entire game.Lastly, the game’s big gimmick is parachuting to any place on the battlefield. I never once learned how to land correctly. The instructions were not very clear, and after failing all three times in the tutorial, I was approved and sent off to war. I played every mission, and made countless landings, and botched every single one. I was upset that I couldn’t do it, but even more upset that I couldn’t LEARN to do it.This game was a novelty when I was looking for something I hadn’t played before, but it’s not something I’ll ever go back to with fond memories.

												I am a pretty big fan of the good ol' Medal of Honor series, but as much as it hurts to say this, I can't really recommend this one. Yeah, I've played for mere minutes, but there's a reason for that. First off, upon my first start up of the game, I was waiting ever so patiently for it to install all the useless stuff, only for it to tell me that my graphics card is not supported. Now, because I have an Intel HD 4200, I can understand why this wouldn't work. Obviously, I wasn't gonna call it a day there. I looked around, searched the forums, the Googles, and found something called PhysX Legacy. Several places said installing this would make it work. Did that, no difference.I then found someone saying to just rename the setup .exe in the games files, and upon doing that, the game actually started up.And now, to the actual game itself.Because the setup was renamed, the game kinda ignored all the graphical stuff, and does not allow me to mess with the graphics settings. When playing a cutscene, most, if not all the characters are simply black silhouettes. I was watching as one of them was showing me my objective in a town in Italy, which just turned out to be a blank wall. So, if you end up like I did where your card is not suppoted, you can't do much about the cutscenes.Now, the gameplay. The first mission, and probably every single other mission, starts out with you jumping out of a plane. You parachute into the town, your objective to take out AA and artillery guns. Now, this is just my opinion, but I didn't like the fact that it didn't matter what order I completed my objectives. I found myself running through the empty streets, from one side of the town to the other, all of a sudden running into some firefight close to the objective. I've played Allied Assault, European Assault, Rising Sun, Vanguard, and the missions were all linear and not really picky. I think that's how it should have been with Airborne. The idea of choosing how to do the mission is cool, but something about the topic and the way it was executed just makes me think that it's not as good as it could be. In Vanguard, you did the same thing, jump, land, and one by one finish your job. In Airborne, you jump, and you can finish the mission as you please.The shooting is a bit odd to me, but that's probably because I'm used to shooting without iron sights, like in the old MoHs. You can sprint, the health bar is different than just about every other MoH, giving you 4 bars that can regenerate with either health packs or just over time, so long as the bar is not empty. In Vanguard, it worked like CoD, get shot, wait a few, its like nothing happened. In the older ones, you had 100 health, and could only get more if you picked up bottles, medkits, etc.I do not reccomend because the game is simply too much of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to get up and running, and if you have the problem I had, you will not be able to toy around with the graphic settings. Hell, there isn't even an option to do so, other than brightness and whatnot. The multiplayer is also a major disappointment, as there is only 10 or less people playing. Allied Assault has more players than this game, and that's a game from 2002. If you're concerned about the story of it, it's World War 2. Not your forte? Go back to your futuristic bolonga. Medal of Honor Airborne was probably amazing in its day, but in 2014, it only causes problems and disappointment.

												As a veteran of many shooters in last 15 years, I feel pretty comfortable writing this review. Wolfenstein: New World Order actually uses that feature well, but here, it's just infuriating. Seriously, I've never seen this - a game where every movement results in confusion. They got every. Single. Damn. Thing. Wrong.It doesn't even matter that all the singleplayer maps feel like playing a long, tired team deadmatch with bots, that they're completely uninspired and that enemies are absolute morons that run and jump around like rabbits, but become quite dangerous because of their perfect aim and sudden spawn. 												The Good: Decent graphics, different level design approach, fast paced, it doesn't last very longThe Bad: Botched paratrooping mechanic, ridiculously difficult, monotonous level progression, dead multiplayer, brings nothing new to the tired genreMedal of Honor started the first person shooter World War II experience back on the original PlayStation. As time went on they redefined the genre on PC with Allied Assault. It helped put WWII shooter's feet on cinematic ground. Frontline was the series last good game, and slowly after that the series fell flat on its face with mediocrity, with EA only caring about money. Airborne continues this trend and it's dead obvious how little effort they put into the game.You play as a soldier named Travers (like we care at this point) and you go through various WWII scenarios that you have probably gone through dozens of times before. The first thing you will notice about Airborne is how repetitive it feels in comparison to other WWII shooters. It doesn't do anything new and re-treads the same ground that we are sick and tired of. EA tried to make us feel different about this with a new approach to level design. You play as paratroopers that jump out of planes at the start of every level onto green flares. These are safe zones and contain crates of health, ammo, and grenades. Once you hit the ground you will notice that your mini-map is pointing to various objectives. No longer do you follow a linear routine and take it one at a time. Pick a direction and run, but that's when things start going bad.Every map plays out the same, shoot some enemies, push forward, rinse and repeat ad nauseam. The enemies will keep coming in different pockets of the maps until you advance and take them out. This isn't a new trick, and just gets old quick because that is all you do. Place a charge on this AA gun, blow up this equipment, blow up these thanks. No thanks. I have done this countless times already so why do I want to do it here? The whole "non-linear" map idea doesn't really work because it makes the game ridiculously difficult and you will die dozens of times every level. Every time you die you jump back out of the plane loosing not objective progress, but advancement progress. If you just pushed back a huge group of enemies and die you have to do it again. Your objectives are just checkpoints, and this gets frustrating beyond anything you can imagine. The game throws way too many enemies at you, but there are even problems with weapons.The game has a nice upgrade system for doing so many kills. For example, the MP40 will upgrade with a double clip, reduced recoil, and a knife melee attack. This is the most interesting thing in the entire game, but EA for some reason made the guns inaccurate to accommodate for upgrades. Guns jump around more than you are used to and no matter how well your aim is you always miss about 60% of the time. Once you hit the less recoil upgrade it isn't so bad. All the same WWII era weapons are here (except the Sten) and it is yawn worthy.Thankfully the game is short with only 6 levels, so you can beat the game in about 6 hours. No matter how you slice it the game is just extremely hard, repetitive, boring, and unoriginal on every level. They even went back to the health pack system which is just archaic in design. You would think at least jumping out of planes is fun? Not really because if you don't grease or flare your landing you botch it and it involves a nauseating and disorienting animation of your character wobbling around while getting up and pulling the weapon out in a weird way. While this is happening guys are shooting you and you will recover with one health bar left. Nice job EA for screwing every single thing in a game up that you possibly could. Even the graphics are pretty bland and aren't anything special.Overall, Airborne is probably the worst Medal of Honor game I have ever played. Monotonous shooting, ridiculous difficulty, screwed up paratrooping mechanic, failed level design, and a retread of a genre everyone is tired of. Call Of DerpyI was sooo close to recommending this game.  I had one mission to go and I figured I might as well finish it before posting my thoughts on it.  It turns out the game's last mssion was effectively unplayable for me.  The rest of the game was just fine.  The last mission was a glitchy, stuttery parade of pain and frustration.  I gave up and uninstalled the game with extreme prejudice.The game is like a generational bridge between the old Playstation 2 Medal of Honor games and the more modern Call of Duty games.  If you have never played a Medal of Honor game before, you will probably be saying to yourself "COD does this so much better" as you play.  And it is largely true.  But those of you who have played Medal of Honor since the series started will find some nostalgic fun factor here.The game also introduces a unique element to the series; verticality.  I don't mean wall-running or double-jumping like modern shooters.  But landing on the battlefield via parachute means you can go land anywhere.  On roofs, scaffolding, etc.  and you can also leap or climb to places that was not possible in the classic MoH games.  Enemies can be placed in high places as well and this adds a subtle new twist on the series.EA took a bold but awkward direction with this game.  They invested time and money into new (for the time) rag-doll physics technology.  Most of the time it's pretty impressive.  Most of the time.  Enemies you kill may stiffen and then fall backwards, or they may lose all motor control and slump over.  When I compare this to the death animations in Call of Duty: World At War, I like this better (most of the time).  Yeah, COD:WaW has dismemberment and more blood, but in this game they have a better sense of weight.But then there are the other times...  Times when the rag doll simulation isn't so natural.  Maybe 5% of the time it just looks weird.  And then there is that 1% of the time where it just gets SILLY!  Bodies will pop five feet in the air, or shake violently.  One time I saw the enemies gun got stuck in a wall and the corpse's hand would not let go of it.  Other times a dead enemy's body part will get stuck on... nothing.  It will hang from the air.  It can get pretty ridiculous and you will get a chuckle now and then.  Sometimes the derpy physics will even effect YOU.  And you don't have to be dead for it to happen.  I was walking along and I was suddenly tossed 15 feet to one side like I was hit by an invisible car.Like all of the classic Medal of Honor games the enemies seem to get more durable as the game progresses.  On the last mission I was using my sniper rifle almost exclusively because the other weapons seemed to do very little.  Some enemies required more than one hit with the sniper rifle.The game starts pretty slow but it gets pretty fun in the middle.  Operation Market Garden was quite fun.But the game went completely crapular for me on the last mission.  Wildly uneven and stuttery frame rates, graphical and audio glitches constantly.  Controlling the player was difficult and laggy with each stutter.  When things started moving again I would find I had completely oversteered or walked farther than I intended.  I use a 6-core i7 and a GTX960.  There is no reason a game of this age should suddenly act like this.  The crazy level of difficulty on the final mission combined with the glitch fest was too much for me.  I tried for several hours to complete the final mission but just gave up and uninstalled the game after it had depleted my very last drop of resolve.The game is quite fun in the middle.  But I can not recommend it.  2 or 3 fun missions is not enough to warrant a purchase.  Esp. if it decides to break down on you for the last mission.  Maybe get it if it is dramatically discounted in price.

												Having rented this game back on the xbox around the time it came out, I had fond memories of a slightly above average WW2 shooter with some great levels. Unfortunately, it seems that nostalgia clouded my recollection of this game.  While not terrible, it is certainly no more than an average WW2 shooter.  Question is, is it worth $10?If you have an itch to replay the highly oversaturated WW2 genre of the 2000's, then I would say this game is worth the ten bucks.  If you are just looking for a fun shooter, save your money for one of the million better FPS games out there.The hook for this game that attempts to seperate it from other WW2 shooters is that you are a paratrooper.  This is reflected in the the level design through the gameplay mechanic of you begining  the levels by jumping out of a plane and steering where you want to start.  It's an intresting (if a bit shallow) gameplay mechanic that lends to some fun replay value for a few levels.  For example, do you land on streets with your allies, or behind enemy lines in the thick of things? Landing on roofs, towers, and german soldiers before ambushing them is probably the best part of this game.As for the shooting itself, its pretty sub par.  Often the bullets will miss their targets for no reason, even when aiming directly at enemies. I understand that the sub machines guns should have a shorter range then rifles, but its just way too short to be taken seriously.  While long range shooting can be more effective, it takes way too long to pick off enemies from a distance, leading to tedious games of whack a mole while germans run around taking multiple shots to the head.  Close range combat is much more fun, but due to the sloopy shooting mechanics its quite dangerous.  In later levels, where the enemies become quite tough, its just not an option you can rely on, and you'll be back to tedious cover shooting.  Another thing to note concerning the shooting and weaponry is that allied weapons become pretty obsolete in the long run.  Since you are  a paratrooper and are dropping into enemy territory, there are not many american weapons laying around.  Since you burn ammo fast due to crappy shooting, you'll often rely on german weapons (which in my opinion are better anyways).  Since you use them more, your weapons will "level up" and upgrade faster, which flat out makes them objectively better.  You can even select them from the drop load out, so there is really no purpose for allied weapons.The AI in this game is attrocious.  On your side, your allies are completely useless, standing around and shooting at walls.  The most notable thing they do is step in front of you when you are priming grenades and zooming through scopes, and they are SKILLED at diving in front of your rockets.  As for the enemy AI, it ranges from dead as a doorknob to spawn of hitler.  The AI will often charge you with no sense of self preservation, with sometimes multiple nazi officers running in front of a firing squad to try and melee you.  It also seems that the nazis were researching into psychic powers, as if you aim at an enemy they will literally instantly know where you are and that you are aiming at them.  I cannot count how many times I went to flank an enemy or snuck up on one from a distance only to have them make miracle dodges or just turn around and snipe me.  The AI also only guns for you, which is very annoying.  Simply put, the AI is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.As for the levels themselves, they range from tedious to imaginative.  There are only six levels in the game, and with multiplayer being dead this is all you have to play with.  I would say two of the levels are great, two are average, one is sub par, and one is♥♥♥♥♥♥  The last level in particular is the most memorable, and encompases the best that the game has to offer.As for the technical side of things, this game is clearly a console port slapped onto PC.  The controls are fine, but the engine doesnt take advantage of the PC and the draw distance is pretty short, which is very noticeable when dropping.  Also, there is WAY TOO MUCH motion blur in this game.  It really can hurt your eyes if you have a larger montior. Before rounding out this review, I should mention there are quite a few MURRIKA moments in this game, complete with wailing trumpets and dripping patriotisim.  Its pretty stupid sometimes, and the story is completely forgetable.  It's actually nonexistent, now that I think about it.  There are no real characters and there is no real plot to follow.  Its just shooting things in WW2.SO, in the end, I would recomend this game ONLY if you really want to play a simple WW2 shooter that isn't Call of Duty. At $10 it's not a rip off, but its not really a deal either.

												MoHA was suppose to breath new life into what was a somewhat dying franchise. Instead it killed it so hard that it needed a reboot that also didn't live up to expectation. It only takes a few hours of playing to see the faults.First off, the concept is not bad on paper. At the start of each mission, you get to jump out of a plane, and land where you want. Again, great on paper, but the reality of it is that there are very few places you can actually safely land without becoming a bullet sponge. It also gets real ♥♥♥♥ing annoying that you have to do this over and over each time you die.The next problem is the lean/cover system. The idea is again, good on paper. Whilst aiming down sights, you can lean or go prone using the movement keys, or move slowly by holding the sprint key. The problem is that this doesn't work under stress. I'm use to being able to move whilst in iron sights, and I am use to using other buttons for lean. There is a reason this has not been used again.EA obviously saw Crysis and thought it would be a good idea and put it into a WWII game, therefore it has a 'non-linear' level form. This doesn't ♥♥♥♥ing fit with the theme. These are well-planned military operations. People go certain places and do certain jobs in a certain order. You don't just run around willy-nilly doing whatever objective seems like it would be the funnest. AI is a ♥♥♥♥ing joke. Allies constantly rush towards Nazis and die quickly. They also have a habit of getting in the way of you when you are trying to ♥♥♥♥ing shoot someone. The enemies themselves constantly leave cover.The difficulty comes from a few parts of this game. First of all, health drops are barely around. THIS IS A HUGE ♥♥♥♥ING PROBLEM. It really ♥♥♥♥ing sucks dying after playing for 10 minutes, because there are no ♥♥♥♥ing health kits available. It's not hard to add a few health kits. It's simple level design. You also can die really quickly. MG 42s tear you apart before you can blink. Enemies can bum rush you and melee you to death. I've had enemies do this to me, whilst surviving automatic gunfire. It's complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Apart from that, damage does seem fairly balanced. Now I understand an MG 42 would tear you apart in real life, but this isn't ARMA, and it's sure as hell annoying having to go back to a checkpoint when you are just rapidly killed by an MG 42 nest that you either couldn't kill in time, or didn't see. The weapon-upgrade system is pretty meh. I don't understand some of the upgrades. For example, the shotgun gets a bayonet, but why not instead the M1 Garand? 												MoHA was suppose to breath new life into what was a somewhat dying franchise. Instead it killed it so hard that it needed a reboot that also didn't live up to expectation. It only takes a few hours of playing to see the faults.First off, the concept is not bad on paper. At the start of each mission, you get to jump out of a plane, and land where you want. Again, great on paper, but the reality of it is that there are very few places you can actually safely land without becoming a bullet sponge. It also gets real ♥♥♥♥ing annoying that you have to do this over and over each time you die.The next problem is the lean/cover system. The idea is again, good on paper. Whilst aiming down sights, you can lean or go prone using the movement keys, or move slowly by holding the sprint key. The problem is that this doesn't work under stress. I'm use to being able to move whilst in iron sights, and I am use to using other buttons for lean. There is a reason this has not been used again.EA obviously saw Crysis and thought it would be a good idea and put it into a WWII game, therefore it has a 'non-linear' level form. This doesn't ♥♥♥♥ing fit with the theme. These are well-planned military operations. People go certain places and do certain jobs in a certain order. You don't just run around willy-nilly doing whatever objective seems like it would be the funnest. AI is a ♥♥♥♥ing joke. Allies constantly rush towards Nazis and die quickly. They also have a habit of getting in the way of you when you are trying to ♥♥♥♥ing shoot someone. The enemies themselves constantly leave cover.The difficulty comes from a few parts of this game. First of all, health drops are barely around. THIS IS A HUGE ♥♥♥♥ING PROBLEM. It really ♥♥♥♥ing sucks dying after playing for 10 minutes, because there are no ♥♥♥♥ing health kits available. It's not hard to add a few health kits. It's simple level design. You also can die really quickly. MG 42s tear you apart before you can blink. Enemies can bum rush you and melee you to death. I've had enemies do this to me, whilst surviving automatic gunfire. It's complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Apart from that, damage does seem fairly balanced. Now I understand an MG 42 would tear you apart in real life, but this isn't ARMA, and it's sure as hell annoying having to go back to a checkpoint when you are just rapidly killed by an MG 42 nest that you either couldn't kill in time, or didn't see. The weapon-upgrade system is pretty meh. I don't understand some of the upgrades. For example, the shotgun gets a bayonet, but why not instead the M1 Garand? It makes more sense as the shotgun is designed for close quarters. IT'S A SHOTGUN FOR ♥♥♥♥S SAKE! The M1 however is better at long range, and it would make sense that if an enemy catches you off guard that you may have to stick them.Story is non-existent. There is no reason to care about your fellow soldiers. They're just cannon fodder. Just go mission to mission shooting that and blowing up this. I honestly couldn't care less by the second mission.Here's an idea, how about make it you're the squad leader, and during mission planning, you choose where to drop. Maybe one drop gets you closer to the enemy, but is very risky, or one takes you to close to good high ground where you can pick off some Germans. This would give merit to the whole 'jumping out of a plane' gimmick, and allowed for a more interesting game. Having played Allied Assault, I can easily say its a much better game, despite being much older. Brothers in Arms: Hell's Highway was also based around paratroopers, but did everything much better (except you don't get to jump out of a plane). 8/10 Major Fret's would send this game to the gas chamber.

												Very solid FPS set in WWII.The campaign consists of 6 long missions and offers 3 difficulty levels. I've played on the highest (Expert) and each mission took me ~ 90-120 minutes (with the exception of the last one which required a LOT of tries) due to slower approach.I haven't played multi-player yet (and probably never will) so I can't review that part of the game.Things I liked:- Non-linear approach which allows me to land almost anywhere and choose the way I want to beat the given part - this is definitely a unique selling point of the game.- Wide selection of weapons and their upgrades. Each weapon has 3 upgrade which gradually unlock after given number of kills.- Enemy A.I. which utilizes cover and even though the enemies don't respawn, they're able to create a very tight defense which can provide very long gunfights.- Cover system which makes the Expert difficulty challenging, but still fair.- Springfield rifle; the best in-game weapon, hands down.Things I disliked:- Unbalanced difficulty in case of otherwise fantastic last level. Groups of MG-42 wielding elite soldiers which can take you down in a second, combined with sparse checkpoints can be quite frustrating.- Severe lack of physics. Soldiers are the only in-game entities which are affected by a physics system, which is quite flawed. Some soldiers get thrown back by 5 meters when hit by a bullet. Some others fly 20 meters up when hit by a grenade. Fortunately, these hilarious events are not that common.- Weird hitboxes. Some soldiers can survive 2 headshots while others die immediately when hit in their foot.- Censorship. I hate Nazis as much as the next guy, but replacing the swastika by a different symbol (regular symmetric cross) is not the right solution, especially in case of a game which takes place during an important part of history. The same with almost no blood - it makes a war game more fun to play which doesn't feel.... right.Nonetheless, I enjoyed the game and will probably play it again some time in the future - and I'd recommend you to do the same.

												Pretty decent World War II FPS. The market's pretty saturated with these types of games, IMHO, and this one's very similar in premise to, say, COD:WaW. You get a gun, you mow down Nazis, occasionally face against German tanks. That's it. The missions feel very same-y, with plant explosives at A, then go to point B and do the same, before heading to point C and repeating it again. But the unique part is that the missions are semi-open world. You can do them in any order. You can go do C, before backtracking to A and then completing B. What I like the most is the weapon progression system. Use enough of a weapon and you 'level up' your skill with that particular weapon and unlock attachments for them. For example, you get increased damage for the M1911 for example, and a scope for the STG-44 (which is a horrible attachment to be honest).So, is it any good then? Well, if you enjoyed the simple run and gun type of gameplay of, say, the older Medal of Honours and the million WW2 shooters back then, then you will like this one. Pick it up while it's on sale though for some simple FPS fun.

												MOH has always been an outstanding series in the FPS genre.  Until, of course, their recent and final release known as Warfighter.  Airborne puts you in a position of the 82nd Airborne division.  Just like Vanguard, you push up through Sicily and into France to clear the way for Operation Overlord; also known as D-Day.  For a game that released almost seven years ago, its still amazing.  Yeah the controls are a little wacky, especially with the ADS when it comes to completely stopping.  After getting use to the controls, its fun and easy.  What I always liked about the MOH series, is that as you progress through the campaign, the missions get harder no matter the difficulty.  The campaign is a good 5-6 hours depending on how much time you take.  Every time you die, the game respawns you back in the plane.  Now, that does sound bad, but it isn't actually, since you get to parachute back down to whatever objectives that was not finished.  I think it was the right step to take when developing this game.Due to its 32-bit limitations (if pc is 64-bit) it will break in the setup menu.  Just accept everything and start it from there.  The game would keep crashing if you do not proceed.  Everything else that's in the game, I would rather for you to figure it out and expierence yourself.  Ima give this game an 8.9/10 just due to the 32-bit limitations.

												Medal of Honor: Airborne is a fair game, well worth buying. It presents fictional battles during WWII that nevertheless play off of the main storyline. You take the place of an American paratrooper, who works to eliminate the Nazis. Airborne presents a useful upgrading system, where you can improve several weapons based on the number of kills you receive for each. The controls are familiar, but present some new functions that work like a charm, once you get used to them. I did see some small blood puffs, but took a keen eye to place them. The graphics for this game are fairly good, doing a very good job of using the environment and lighting to generate an atmosphere that, along with the soundtrack, fit Airborne like a glove. As for the gameplay itself, I want to say this--Casual is Casual, Normal is Normal, Veteran is Veteran. I highly suggest getting used to the game before advancing to higher levels. The enemies are also class-based--they certainly get tougher later in the game. This is perfectly exemplified by the deadly Nazi Storm Elite trooper, who wears a bulletproof vest, a gas mask, and walks calmly along while carrying a mini-gun. I will never encounter anything scarier in a game than walking around a corner to find myself face-to-face with this horror. All in all, Airborne is a good game, and is definitely worth buying
